urn:contentItem:6380-6DF1-F0HF-8217-00000-00Mexican firefighters to assist in B.C.2021-07-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A18Mexican firefighters to assist in B.C.

A contingent of Mexican firefighters has been deployed to aid British Columbia’s fire effort.

The 100 fire fighters are the first international crew to come to B.C. ’s aid and were expected to arrive in Abbotsford July 24. They will be deployed to work on fires in the Interior under the direction of B.C. Wildfire Service.

Personnel from New Brunswick, Alberta and Quebec are already active in B.C. , as well as experts from Parks Canada. Twenty more firefighters from Quebec joined yesterday July 16.

“We appreciate the firefighting assistance we’re receiving from other Canadian provinces and from Mexico,” said Katrine Conroy, B.C. Minister of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development in a press release.

The Mexican firefighters will be tested for COVID-19 upon departure and arrival. They will work and live in operational bubbles, separate from B.C. crews in order to minimize the risk of COVID-19 transmissions. They will also be offered access to vaccines.

The cost of bringing in firefighting personnel from other provinces, or countries, is covered by the B.C. government. Incoming firefighters are trained by the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre (CIFFC) to meet Canadian standards before being deployed to where needed most.

“These crews are a welcome addition to our own firefighters and contractors, who are working extremely hard to help keep B.C.

communities safe,” said Conroy.

Mexican firefighters have helped B.C. in previous fire seasons and resources are often shared internationally. Similarly, Canadian firefighters where deployed to Australia in early 2020. More international aid seems highly likely as the smoky summer progresses.

“We’re deploying all available resources to respond to hundreds of wildfires across the province, and will continue to do everything possible to protect communities,” said Mike Farnworth, B.C. Minister of Public Safety.

Revelstoke Review Staff

urn:contentItem:6380-6DF1-F0HF-81N4-00000-00WFP announces $50,000 donation for wildfire relief and readiness efforts2021-07-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A4WFP announces $50,000 donation for wildfire relief and readiness efforts

Western Forest Products Inc.has made a donation of $50,000 to the Canadian Red Cross BC Fires Appeal Campaign.

With the provincial and federal governments matching donations to support the Canadian Red Cross campaign in B.C. , this brings the total contribution to $150,000. The donation will be used to support impacted communities with immediate relief efforts, along with long term recovery and preparedness for future events.

“This is a tremendously difficult time for individuals and families and our thoughts are with all of those impacted, including community residents, first responders and volunteers,” said Don Demens, WFP’s president and chief executive officer. “We are proud to support the Canadian Red Cross and will continue to do what we can to assist emergency responders in the communities where we operate to help keep communities safe.

“Safety is a core value at Western and the potential devastation that wildfires pose to communities is top of mind during the fire season. Staff members of our timberlands’ operations are trained in forest fire fighting and often are the first responders on scene, due to our comprehensive knowledge of the terrain and the remote nature of our tenures. Western is intimately connected to the communities where we operate, and we assist with personnel and equipment to fight fires and keep individuals and communities safe through our long-standing partnership with B.C. Wildfire Services.”

Western is an integrated forest products company building a margin-focused log and lumber business to compete successfully in global softwood markets. Operations and employees are located primarily on the coast of B.C. , including Chemainus, and Washington State.

Western has a long-term commitment towards investing in community needs in the areas where its employees live and work. Through Western’s Community Enhancement Fund, the company provides support to local community events, organizations and initiatives.

The Courier

urn:contentItem:6615-MS91-JD2C-J40Y-00000-00Hug your air conditioner today2022-07-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisOPINIONHug your air conditioner today

Do you remember last year's heat dome? How it went on and on and on? How it made the forest fire situation so much worse? How one could actually get sick of seeing the sun every day?

We are thankfully experiencing a much nicer summer this year, but don't kid yourself, hot, hot, hot summers are going to become more the norm as our climate changes.

One of the things I did this year in anticipation of another hot summer was to get a portable air conditioner. Even if it hasn't been as hot, it has still become my new best friend.

According to BC Hydro, air conditioner use in the province has tripled since 2001, rising to 34 per cent of homes. BC Hydro sees that trend continuing.

While we in B.C. are actually having a pretty ideal summer, that is not the case for much of the world. Europe is having an extreme heat wave right now, and it has been going on for almost a month. A glacier collapsed in Italy at the beginning of the month, and 11 people were killed. Another glacier in Kyrgyzstan collapsed a few days later. Thankfully no one was hurt in that incident. Spain is also experiencing extreme heat, and the accompanying forest fires. As is France.

And England is also suffering in 40 degree heat. As anyone who has travelled to Europe can tell you, most of the architecture is old. It's charming and beautiful and in no way built for 40 degree temperatures. In fact much of it, particularly in England, which historically is not known for hot, sunny days, is actually designed to retain heat, to keep it in on those cool, rainy days so typical to the British climate.

It is estimated that less than five per cent of British homes have air conditioning. That number goes up a bit for Europe as a whole but until these heat waves started happening with more regularity, Europe had a pretty mild summer climate, and people just put up with a few days of 30 plus weather each year. But the number of a/c units are rising.

I know with myself, one heat dome event was all I needed to convince me to invest in one.

But even parts of the world that are very used to heat, and where air conditioning is simply a part of life, are facing some issues.

The New York Times reported that nearly 35 million people in Texas and the central plains were under excessive heat warnings last week. And in Texas, while you can turn down the a/c to alleviate the heat, the power supplier ERCOT, has asked people not to do that. They ask instead that you reduce electricity use to avoid rolling blackouts.

Now, in most places in North America, if one power grid is facing extreme use, power can be diverted from a connecting grid that is not so stressed. But not in Texas. That state, which prides itself on independence, is not connected the national grids. They didn't want any crazy federal rules governing their own power. So they are on their own, and, as was proven by an unprecedented cold snap in February 2021, independence comes at a price.

The power system in Texas simply couldn't hold up during the Arctic weather and people actually froze to death in their homes.

And now with another extreme heat event in the southern states, a state full of air conditioned homes is asking resident to please don't use the a/c so much. So hurray for independence, I guess.

In B.C. our power supply seems fairly secure. BC Hydro assures customers that although demand is rising, so that summer demand can have peaks as large as those in winter, there are plenty of supply options to meet that need. We have surplus electricity in this province and BC Hydro says we have more than we will need until 2030. After that, well plans are being made to meet future demand through a combination energy conservation and developing more generation.

That's another reason B.C. is a good place to be. Excuse me, I am off to hug my air conditioner.

urn:contentItem:62WN-93D1-JD2C-J2KF-00000-00Expect a warm summer for Revelstoke: Environment Canada2021-06-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A27Expect a warm summer for Revelstoke: Environment Canada

Revelstoke should expect this hot weather to continue into the summer, according to Environment Canada.

Te m p e r a t u r e s reached 32 degrees Celsius in Revelstoke on June 2, which is higher than usual for this time of year.

“We’re getting a taste of summer,” said Lisa Erven, meteorologist.

While most of the province had a drier May than usual, Revelstoke had a wet month at almost 50 millimetres of rain. Last year, the city received less than 30 mm.

After seeing its driest March on record this year, Kelowna just experienced its driest May to date as well.

That month, the city only saw 3.5 mm of rain. Typically it would get 40.2 mm.

Erven said the rest of June for Revelstoke will be a rollercoaster of warm and cool weather, with temperatures heating up locally by July and August to above normal.

Weather Network chief meteorologist Chris Scott said B.C. could be at a high risk for forest fires this summer. However, he predicts the northern parts of the province could have higher-than-normal levels of precipitation.

Regardless, June is typically the wettest month in this part of Canada, he noted, and if that patterns hold true this year it could help diminish the forest fire risk this summer.

While tulips are blooming in downtown Revelstoke, the surrounding peaks are still cloaked in white. In Glacier National Park at the Fidelity weather station (1,905 metres elevation), the snowpack depth was 253 centimetres on June 1. In 2020, on the same date snow depth was 243 cm and for 2019 it was 150 cm.

urn:contentItem:637N-WR61-F0HF-813F-00000-00Mexican firefighters bring relief2021-07-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisREGIONALPg. 20Mexican firefighters bring relief

A contingent of Mexican firefighters has been deployed to aid British Columbia’s fire effort.

The 100 firefighters are the first international crew to come to B.C.’s aid and are expected to arrive in Abbotsford July 24. They will be deployed to work on fires in the Interior under the direction of B.C. Wildfire Service.

Personnel from New Brunswick, Alberta and Quebec are already active in B.C., as well as experts from Parks Canada. Twenty more firefighters from Quebec joined yesterday July 16.

“We appreciate the firefighting assistance we’re receiving from other Canadian provinces and from Mexico,” said Katrine Conroy, B.C. Minister of Forests, Lands, Natural Resource Operations and Rural Development in a press release.

The Mexican firefighters will be tested for COVID-19 upon departure and arrival. They will work and live in operational bubbles, separate from B.C. crews in order to minimize the risk of COVID-19 transmissions. They

will also be offered access to vaccines.

The cost of bringing in firefighting personnel from other provinces, or countries, is covered by the B.C. government. Incoming firefighters are trained by the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre (CIFFC) to meet Canadian standards before being deployed to where needed most.

“These crews are a welcome addition to our own firefighters and contractors, who are working extremely hard to help keep B.C. communities safe,” said Conroy.

Mexican firefighters have helped B.C. in previous fire seasons and resources are often shared internationally.

Similarly, Canadian firefighters where deployed to Australia in early 2020. More international aid seems highly likely as the smoky summer progresses.

“We're deploying all available resources to respond to hundreds of wildfires across the province, and will continue to do everything possible to protect communities,” said Public Safety Minister Mike Farnworth.

urn:contentItem:63JR-0FP1-F0HF-809W-00000-00B.C. Liberal party leader candidate Ellis Ross visits Burns Lake2021-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisNEWSB.C. Liberal party leader candidate Ellis Ross visits Burns Lake

As part of a tour of Northern B.C. Candidate Ellis Ross, who's running to be provincial leader of the Liberal Party, visited Burns Lake to speak to local residents at Spirit Square. Accompanied by Member of Legislative Assembly (MLA) of the Nechako Lakes John Rustad, Ross spent Sept. 2 travelling to various towns in the area.

Lakes District News spoke to Rustad, who said that Ross is one of six candidates for the vacant position after after former Liberal provincial leader Andrew Wilkinson stepped down six months ago. The election will take place on Feb. 5, 2022.

Ross who was elected as MLA for Skeena in 2017 and re-elected in 2020, also spoke to Lakes District News about what he hoped to accomplish from the tour.

"We're in the process of putting a platform together, so this tour is about going out and talking to communities and asking what's important to them," said Ross.

He went on to say that one of his strong positions is on the provincial firefighting services. "We have to re-think how we plan, and cooperate with municipalities. We should be global leaders in fighting fires, which is why I've proposed a forest fire fighting institute with seed money of $78 million," said Ross.

Ross stated that he believes the province should be looking at new technologies and techniques and learning from the past.

"We need to take lessons from the past and look forward. What happened in the community of Monte Lake [near Kamloops] for example, was devastating. People lost their lives, they lost everything. I want to try to ensure that doesn't happen to any of our communities moving forward."

The deadline to become a member to vote for the Liberal leader of B.C. is on Dec. 17, 2021.

urn:contentItem:63J9-1HJ1-JD2C-J1SP-00000-00Tegart: Leadership of parents, educators will bring another successful school year to SD 782021-09-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisTegart: Leadership of parents, educators will bring another successful school year to SD 78

As September rolls around and our schools reopen their doors to students, British Columbians were hoping we wouldn't be facing many of the same challenges our education system and communities faced last year. Unfortunately, as our province tackles the fourth wave of COVID and case numbers continue to rise, our families and education staff are going to have to approach this September with the same level of caution as before.

It was through the incredible resilience of our teachers and support staff as well as the compassion and commitment of parents and families that our students were able to continue their education last year despite the incredible challenges of COVID — and it is through their guidance and leadership that we must navigate these opening months of this school year.

As your MLA and the Official Opposition's Education Critic, I will be spending these crucial months connecting with community advocates, school districts, teachers and support staff to help lobby government to provide the additional supports our schools and staff need. This includes distance learning options for students, HVAC and improved ventilation in schools, and additional funding for PPE and protective measures in classrooms.

READ MORE: Tegart: Local communities and leaders invaluable in forest fire recovery efforts

COVID is not the only challenge our schools and communities have faced this past year, and the fall will mark another important time for our local communities here in the Interior — a time for us to re-evaluate our province's response to this year's devastating wildfire season.

It is the thousands of community members, emergency responders, volunteers and First Nations who have been on the front line fighting these fires and protecting our communities who must lead our province in our re-evaluation of government supports available so that we have the resources we need to keep our businesses, homes, and families safe from future fire seasons.

Together, we will keep our kids learning and our communities safe no matter what this year may throw at us.

urn:contentItem:6391-NP41-F103-34KC-00000-00Wildfire crew looking for newly started fire finds B.C. hiker missing for 2 weeks2021-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisNEWSWildfire crew looking for newly started fire finds B.C. hiker missing for 2 weeks

A wildfire attack crew looking for a newly started forest fire instead found a man who had been missing in the rugged backcountry of Garibaldi Provincial Park, north of Vancouver.

A statement from Squamish RCMP says the hiker missing in the park for two weeks was found safe on Thursday.

A search for 33-year-old Daniel Ring began July 9.

Bryan Zandberg, an information assistant with the B.C. Wildfire Service's Coastal Fire Centre, said a three-person crew and a helicopter pilot were on their way to investigate a report of a fire when they spotted the man.

"They saw somebody down on the ground, arms waving and signalling for help," Zandberg said.

The area where Ring was spotted is very remote, he said.

"I can only imagine being lost for two weeks. I look at the map and he was in Elfin Lakes where they found him. It's quite a distance."

Police said Ring had been dropped off in the park on July 7 for a solo trek and was reported overdue when he failed to meet up as planned.

The statement from RCMP says "there was literal cheer" in the detachment when members of Coastal Fire reported they found Ring.

Cpl. Angela Kermer did not provide an update on his condition but said police have "connected him with his family."

Zandberg said it was only after the crew landed to help the man that they found out he'd been missing.

The crew flew him to a waiting ambulance and RCMP, then went back to investigate the fire they were originally called about, he said.

"I think everybody's really glad he was found," Zandberg said. "It's a silver lining, for sure."

urn:contentItem:68B0-RB01-F197-501M-00000-00UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program2023-05-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisNEWSUPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program

Mississauga's photo radar cameras were activated in summer 2021 and the city's program is expanding. Here are a few things to know about Mississauga's speed cameras, including their locations.

Timeline

Mississauga council approved the city's automated speed enforcement (ASE) program as part of the 2020 budget, with the original launch date planned for September of that year.

City staff said delays related to the COVID-19 pandemic slowed down the roll-out of the program.

In May, now former Ward 9 Coun. Pat Saito successfully moved a motion to accelerate plans for more speed cameras in the city, boosting the program from two cameras to 22 by the end of 2021.

The City of Mississauga's first two photo radar cameras became active July 5 in 2021 with units in Malton and Erin Mills neighbourhoods.

City officials said they planned to activate the remaining 20 speed cameras by the end of 2021. According to a report from the city, all 22 were operational by April 2022.

As of Thursday, May 25, 18 speed cameras were active, according to the city.

Tickets

City staff estimated in 2020 that 22 photo radar units would generate 160,000 charges annually.

According to a Mississauga press release, 495 speeding tickets came from the first two speed camera locations, Morning Star Drive and Sawmill Valley Drive, which were in place from July 5 to the first week of August 2021.

In an emailed statement, the city's road safety supervisor Colin Patterson wrote that Mississauga's photo-radar cameras issued another 4,827 speeding tickets between August and December of 2021.

As of June 3, the city reported that 8,258 tickets have been issued in total for the program but only around 25 per cent of the associated fines had been paid.

During that time approximately 1,600 additional vehicles were caught speeding by the city's photo-radar units but were not ticketed due in part to a provincial requirement to issue fines within 30 days of the offence.

At least 23,000 tickets were issued through the photo-radar program in 2022.

urn:contentItem:636V-J831-DY9S-T3JG-00000-00Wildfire crew looking for newly started fire finds B.C. hiker missing for two weeks2021-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisPRAIRIES/BC,NATIONALWildfire crew looking for newly started fire finds B.C. hiker missing for two weeksThe Canadian Press

SQUAMISH, B.C. - A wildfire attack crew looking for a newly started forest fire instead found a man who had been missing in the rugged backcountry of Garibaldi Provincial Park, north of Vancouver.

A statement from Squamish RCMP says the hiker missing in the park for two weeks was found safe on Thursday.

A search for 33-year-old Daniel Ring began July 9.

Bryan Zandberg, an information assistant with the B.C. Wildfire Service's Coastal Fire Centre, said a three-person crew and a helicopter pilot were on their way to investigate a report of a fire when they spotted the man.

“They saw somebody down on the ground, arms waving and signalling for help," Zandberg said.

The area where Ring was spotted is very remote, he said.

“I can only imagine being lost for two weeks. I look at the map and he was in Elfin Lakes where they found him. It’s quite a distance."

Police said Ring had been dropped off in the park on July 7 for a solo trek and was reported overdue when he failed to meet up as planned.

The statement from RCMP says "there was literal cheer" in the detachment when members of Coastal Fire reported they found Ring.

Cpl. Angela Kermer did not provide an update on his condition but said police have "connected him with his family."

Zandberg said it was only after the crew landed to help the man that they found out he'd been missing.

The crew flew him to a waiting ambulance and RCMP, then went back to investigate the fire they were originally called about, he said.

"I think everybody's really glad he was found," Zandberg said. “It’s a silver lining, for sure."

This report by The Canadian Press was first published July 23, 2021.

urn:contentItem:636P-BNJ1-JD2C-J13F-00000-00Quick-thinking Good Samaritans douse brush fire near Big Qualicum River bridge2021-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisNEWSQuick-thinking Good Samaritans douse brush fire near Big Qualicum River bridge

A small brush fire ignited by a hot wheel axle was quickly extinguished thanks to Good Samaritans.

On Wednesday, July 21, at 10:20 a.m., the Bow Horn Bay Volunteer Fire Department, assisted by the Deep Bay Volunteer Fire Department, was called out to an incident along the Inland Island Highway, just north of the Big Qualicum River bridge.

Mark Taylor, deputy chief, said the 400 square foot brush fire was started when the wheel axle of a vehicle towing a boat broke on the southbound lane of the highway. He said the hot axle ended up in a grassy area and ignited flames.

"One good thing was, after the fire started, a bunch of people passing by in their vehicles all pulled over and started putting it out using fire extinguishers," said Taylor.

READ MORE: Potential forest fire averted as firefighters, community members work to douse burning truck in Bowser

"And so when we arrived, the fire was still smouldering. And it was actually the people passing by, who had already left the scene when we arrived, that actually helped to make sure it didn't spread."

He said if the Good Samaritans hadn't been there to do battle as quickly as they had, the fire could've easily turned into something serious.

BC Wildfire was also on scene to survey the area from a helicopter as Bow Horn Bay and Deep Bay firefighters applied water.

Three BC Wildfire firefighters arrived to patrol the area after both departments left to ensure the blaze didn't reignite.

Taylor said both departments were only there for approximately one hour, and no injuries were reported in either the fire or vehicle incident.

urn:contentItem:68NP-B4V1-JCF0-K1T6-00000-00Strategy Session2023-06-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisPOWER PLAY WITH VASSY KAPELOS17:00:00 ETJOYCE NAPIERStrategy Session

DANIELLE SMITH (Alberta Premier): Albertans believe in our promises, and they gave us a mandate to make them happen. And there's a lot of work ahead of us. And that's why I'm so pleased that we have the right team to do the work. Our new cabinet is ready to go, but we won't and we can't do it alone. We will never stop listening to all Albertans, even those who didn't vote for us.

JOYCE NAPIER: Just over a week after securing a majority government for her United Conservative Party, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith unveiled her new cabinet. Some notable appointments include the new health minister Adriana LaGrange who was the former education minister, and former Wildrose party leader Brian Jean is now energy minister. Following her cabinet announcement, the premier was asked about comments she made on the province's devastating wildfire season. In a media interview yesterday, the premier said she was bringing in arson investigators to assess the cause of fires in the province. This after she was asked how her government's oil sands policy square with climate change. She was asked about the issue again today.

SMITH: I think we have to make sure that people understand that human activity causes the vast majority of our wildfires. We've had 609 wildfires this year, 350 of them so far have been determined to be human caused, 104 caused by lightening, 155 are still under investigation. We make sure that every fire that we do not know the cause of that we bring in forensic investigators to be able to examine that. We have forensic fire investigates on staff at Alberta Wildfires and through our national agency the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Association we've made an additional request for forest fire investigators, along with other labour resources, and this request has been met.

NAPIER: Smith went on to explain that she supports the target of carbon neutrality by 2025, but opposes some of the prime minister's policies. And this week on "Power Play," Vassy Kapelos spoke with Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault outside on Parliament Hill when it was blanketed in smoke from Quebec wildfires, and asked what's holding those policies back?

STEVEN GUILBEAULT (Environment Minister): What would greatly help our capacity to accelerate our fight against climate change in Canada is if I didn't have to fight with certain jurisdiction all the time on doing the bare minimum to fight climate change.

NAPIER: So let's take the wildfire politics to our panel of strategists. Greg MacEachern has advised politicians at all three levels of government, and worked on the communications team for national election campaigns. Greg leans Liberal. Fred DeLorey is the former director of political operations for Prime Minister Stephen Harper, and was the 2021 Conservative national campaign manager. He is now a managing partner with DesLauriers Public Affairs. And Anne McGrath is national director of the NDP. Hello, happy Friday. Welcome strategists. So you heard, Fred, you heard Steven Guilbeault saying, you know, it would be a lot easier if everybody was on the same page to put forward and actually make these policies become reality. Is it time sort of for the, to change the message maybe to just not talk too much about climate change for those climate skeptics out there, but just say, look, it's happening, you see it with your own eyes. What can we do about this?

FRED DELOREY (DesLauriers Public Affairs): Look, that's a very tough question, and to be the Conservative here it's tough. Because if you recall two years ago at our national convention, we voted down a motion saying that climate change was real. So there's a lot of, there are still skeptics out there. They feel that. They believe that. Our last leader Erin O'Toole in the last election actually brought in a very comprehensive climate change plan to combat it and fight it, and that was part of the reason why he was overthrown as leader. People brought it up, a lot of caucus that are currently elected fought against him for bringing that in. Now a number of new candidates were elected under that plan, so there is some contention within the Conservative party on that. But ultimately, look, this is real, it's a serious problem we have in front of us, and I do wish we would all again work together as I regularly say to get things moving forward for our country.

NAPIER: So we just heard, and we're going to have to change our topic, you know news is happening, this is a live show. So we can confirm that the special rapporteur, David Johnston, former governor general, has resigned. So let me start with you, Greg MacEachern, are you even surprised?

GREG MACEACHERN (Proof Strategies): Surprised? I guess not, because there, the story, and I can't believe we were supposed to talk about wildfires, I'm from Nova Scotia, you know what I'd rather be talking about than this. And so much was made about this man's reputation. And I know that the, for example, the NDP leader strenuously tried to say I'm not attacking his reputation. But when you watch it on TV, when you see the newspaper, Jagmeet Singh's photo was next to Pierre Poilievre's on this. It has been a terrible time in Canadian politics. The polarization, doesn't matter whatever the issue is, you know we see a lot of polarization, but this was a gentleman's life and career. Did he handle as well as he could have during committee hearings? No. But he was also being attacked for his, for corruption, things that were being said about him, both by elected members and on Twitter. At some point I'm sure he was going to say, look, I'm in my 80s, I don't need this, and perhaps I've become a distract. But I will tell you that there are people that really really were very negative towards him personally, and I don't think history will judge that well.

NAPIER: So the Conservative leader was very much attacking him, personal attacks, you know the ski buddy, and 15 years ago he was praising him when he was actually appointed by the Conservatives, and helped the Conservatives out of a couple of scandals. So was that fair? Is that fair game?

DELOREY: There's nothing fair in politics, and Mr. Poilievre is doing his job to make sure he becomes prime minister in the next election. This was someone that is government appointed, so therefore he was an enemy of the official opposition. That's the view of it, whether it's right or wrong. But this is politics.

MACEACHERN: That's the view of that opposition leader.

DELOREY: Yes.

MACEACHERN: Let's be clear.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

DELOREY: ...from the government. He's doing very well with the polls right now. It's working. And to be fair, and to your point, Greg, the NDP followed Poilievre's lead on this, Poilievre's lead. They followed it.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

MACEACHERN: The other thing is we saw this week that Poilievre pivoted from foreign interference to this weird I guess it was a filibuster, like the way I'm on a plane I'm a pilot, and I think the Conservatives knew that this was not working for them, and this is why they have moved. I don't think Canadians are on board with this. We were told to watch and not under estimate Pierre Poilievre, but the reality is they're ahead in the polls, but by the same amount. It's like three to five points. There's been no growth on this, and there's been a couple of other polls that show it's not working, so I don't think it did work for them.

NAPIER: But it's working now. But I want to hear you, because your leader as well, the NDP leader asked for him to resign as well, so it was a bit of a pile-on, let's face it, in parliament, against a man who's, I understand the appearance of conflict of interest, but we went away from interference and talked more about him, and about his relationship with the prime minister, than this incredibly important issue, or is it not important for politicians, they preferred the personal attacks rather than try to get to the bottom of this?

ANNE MCGRATH (NDP National Director): Well there are a few things to unpack here. First of all he had no choice but to resign in my view based on the motion that was passed by a majority of parliamentarians. I think it's really unfortunate that the Liberal government put him in that position. It was clear that the assumption of, or the perception of bias was weighing that whole process down. I will also point out that Jagmeet Singh attended the meeting that David Johnston, where he testified, and was probably one of the only ones to actually talk about foreign interference in that committee hearing. So I think that his point was that that perception of bias by David Johnston was getting in the way of actually getting to the heart of what was going on with respect to foreign interference. So I think this whole file has been bungled from the very beginning, every single step of the way, and my hope is that now we can actually move on. And my hope is also that the prime minister will accept that a public inquiry is the way to go. I mean with all of the missteps, let's go to where the majority of Canadians want a public inquiry, the majority of experts want a public inquiry.

NAPIER: So this is what is the Conservatives wanted. They wanted him out, as the NDP, the opposition, even though the Bloc, they all wanted him out. So now what?

DELOREY: Well as Mr. Poilievre said, that if a public inquiry is called, he wants a say in who the person is to oversee it. This is going to be very problematic. I don't believe he'll ever agree with what the prime minister is saying, so I don't know where this goes. I think this is going to continue, the political circus will continue on this front.

NAPIER: Where does it go? Where do you go from here? I mean clearly this was supposed to be a process that was going to shed light on something...

MACEACHERN: It's shameful. It's a shameful mark on parliament. My issue with the public inquiry, it would have been so much easier for Justin Trudeau had David Johnston said yes to a public inquiry. And I would like one too if you can tell me how it works. How does it work when you're dealing with...

NAPIER: And how is it different from public hearings?

MACEACHERN: And so, again, Sherry Romanato from the Liberals, to Anne's point about who's asking about foreign interference at the committee, there was one person right there, one Liberal mp that stayed on track with, but most didn't, and really, really bad on the Conservative side. They can never be associated. At some point David Johnston will go on to do something else, and he'll leave this mortal coil at some point, and the Conservatives can never ever point to a great appointment that they made as governor general. But going back to public inquiry, I would like to see how it's going to work. There was a Bloc MP that was telling David Johnston at committee, well you could bring people in and we could just put them in camera. I don't think Canadians think when you're telling them it's going to be a public inquiry you're bringing people in only to put them behind closed doors.

(OVERLAPPING SPEAKERS)

NAPIER: Hang on. Let him finish.

MACEACHERN: That's not the point that was made. It sounds ridiculous! We're going to have a public inquiry so we can bring people in and put them in camera. It sounds silly!

MCGRATH: As we have done many times before.

NAPIER: Yes, we have done it many times before, but both, but all the party leaders were offered to see all these documents. Your leader being the only one who said yes, the Conservative and Bloc Quebecois leaders said no because that's a way to muzzle them which doesn't really hold much water. But I want to read to you the letter that Mr. Johnson wrote to the prime minister, or part of the letter. I have concluded that given the highly partisan atmosphere around my appointment and work, my leadership has had the opposite effect. I'm therefore tendering my resignation effective no later than the end of June, 2023, or as soon as I deliver a brief final report which I hope to be earlier. So, you know, that leaves this whole, you know, Chinese interference, or foreign interference, because it's not only Chinese interference, really kind of up in the air. And, you know, have we gained anything? Is our democracy better off today?

DELOREY: It certainly isn't. We're still talking about this instead of looking at actual legislative solutions how to deal with this problem. And I don't think we're ever going to get there on the way, the route we're all going. All parties are to blame for this now, it's not just one or two, it's not the governing or the opposition, we're all just a complete hot mess in all of this.

NAPIER: So what do you see happening now? So he resigned. Does that mean that his recommendation to not hold a public hearing resigns with him, or does that stay on?

MCGRATH: Well I mean my hope would be that there will be a rethink of this. So the Liberal government has resisted all the way along any attempts to, you know, really kind of bring all of this to light. And so my hope is that they will look at this and say, you know, when you have a majority of Canadians, when you have a majority of experts, and a majority of parliamentarians saying we need a public inquiry, that that should be your next step. And if we had done that back when it was originally proposed by Jagmeet Singh actually, quite some time ago, then we wouldn't have voiced it or lost all this time. And you're right, it hasn't moved forward. You know, you talk about Sherry Romanato in the proc meeting, she pointed out that they hadn't talked about foreign interference, but she didn't actually ask about it either.

MACEACHERN: She did actually. You're confusing her with another MP I think Anne.

MCGRATH: Okay.

MACEACHERN: I watched it fairly closely. Look, the reality of this is who do we get to run the public inquiry? Some AI-generated person that will be, because I don't think this person exists that will make Pierre Poilievre happy. And again, all parties, all opposition party weighed in on this. You described it as pile on. How do we get good people in politics if this is what happens when you have such a pristine reputation as David Johnston and this is the treatment that they get? I mean there were columnists who said well he should have known, but they weren't actually calling out the behaviour, and I think that allowed it to go on. I have been on several of these panels with Conservatives who always say the same thing, I am uncomfortable with what was said about David Johnston. If they are saying that on panels, what is the rest of the country, what is the rest of their party thinking?

NAPIER: So all this is, we started all this because there were leaked reports, Anne, leaked reports in the media because there was those sort of half sentences going around. It became, you know, it was the prime minister, you know, who is practically collaborating with the communist party of China. It's all over the map this story. In the meantime, I'm not sure that most Canadians know the difference between public hearings and a public inquiry, right? I think most Canadians want to know how do you fix, what is it really, because we don't know what it is. We know it's there. We know that there have been certain, but nobody has seen those documents. Your leader is the only one who wants to see those documents. We have two other leaders in parliament who refuse to see any evidence because they say politically it would muzzle them, which I don't think it would.

MACEACHERN: It didn't muzzle Erin O'Toole.

NAPIER: It didn't muzzle Erin O'Toole, and it didn't really muzzle anybody.

MCGRATH: It didn't muzzle anybody. So it is possible to view the documents, and to reach conclusions, and to talk about that without revealing any state secrets, national security secrets, or anything like that, so it's a ridiculous position I believe that the opposition leaders have taken, and I think that Jagmeet Singh has taken the responsible position on this. There has been a lot of hysteria, innuendo, half truths, maybe lies throughout all of this, and a lot of mudslinging, and I think that that has partly been a result of the kind of hyper partisan nature of parliament right now. But also part of it has been missteps and inability to get your arms around a problem, and this is not the first time that we have seen this. We've seen this on many other issues. It's like you figure out what the problem is, where it can go, and go there. Don't keep, don't be always behind the issue which it seems to be the case here.

MACEACHERN: To Anne's point, this is an opportunity for the government. It's probably going to take a while to recalibrate what they're going to do here. But what I was kind of looking for is when the house rose, and the temperature dropped, what is CSIS going to do? There are a huge amount of leaks. We don't talk about the leaks because we're supposed to like them because we see it through the lens of a whistle blower. But we don't know, again we learned the hard way, and some journalists learned this the hard way, intelligence does not equal evidence. So what I'm looking for is CSIS to send some signals to Canadians this summer that they're on top of this.

MCGRATH: Yeah, I think that the leaks were a real problem obviously, and they were leaks not whistle blowing.

NAPIER: Well, but the leaks, Fred, and that's what we're kind of, you weren't quite sure exactly. You knew something has happened. We know that something has happened. We kind of get a few hints of what it is. You know how, but we don't know how it exactly worked. You know, who got money, who didn't get money? How many really, how many ridings? Who was targeted? We know that there are three MPs that were targeted. Are there more MPs that are targeted? What were the nature of the targets, right? So what does the Conservative leader do on Monday when we return, when they return to the house? What does he demand? What does he attack? What does he do?

DELOREY: He is going to demand a public inquiry. He's going to do it tonight. He's going to come again and say that's what we need. That's what he's going to do. Whether it's the right thing, I don't agree with. I think what we need to be focussed on is the problem. We know what the problem is. I was the national campaign manager for the last election. We were told by the security establishment there are legislative gaps. Why isn't parliament looking at what those gaps are and how to figure them out? Everyone is saying public inquiry, let's hire a retired judge to oversee a big process where we go over everything we've already heard. I've gone to committee myself. Lots of people have. Why don't we...

NAPIER: As a campaign manager.

DELOREY: As a campaign manager I was at committee to testify, spent an hour going over everything that I knew and everything I had heard and presenting my evidence. Why aren't we figuring out how to fix these holes, how to plug the holes and make sure that we are ready to go for the next election?

NAPIER: Well, why don't we ask our Liberal strategist, the foreign agents registry. That is something that exists in other countries, US, UK. Okay, they have done all their public consultations, they have gone and consulted experts and other, why is this bill not being drafted as we speak?

MACEACHERN: I would suspect, and I hope it is. I mean one of the things that the United States was able to do with the so-called Chinese police stations, and why they were able to handle those more effectively than Canada was because of their version of this registry. You know, I've seen some counter comments on it that it's going to be tougher than we think, and that's the job of government. They have to be the adult in the room. But I would very much expect that right now that legislation is being drafted and we would be seeing it I think when the parliament returns.

NAPIER: Or maybe even before the end of parliament.

MACEACHERN: That would be nice.

NAPIER: Because that is pressing. What else needs to be done? I know that everybody is calling for the inquiry. The inquiry is just going to kick the can down the road, I think, and then they can have their inquiry. But right now there are things, concrete things, Anne, that can be done, the foreign agents registry so you know who's in your country doing what.

MCGRATH: Yes.

NAPIER: In the name of diplomacy. Okay. What else can be done? Should we upgrade or modernize the RCMP Act, the CSIS Act? What else do we need to do?

MCGRATH: All of these things for sure. And there have been, as Fred said there are legislative gaps that have been identified, those need to be worked on. But I will say that the political problem here is that there are wildfires across the country, unemployment has gone up and it's mostly young people who are losing their jobs, groceries have gone up, rents have gone up, and really while the bubble her is obsessed with this issue, most Canadians are really thinking about the fact that their mortgage rates just went up again this week.

NAPIER: I think we have, because we have to have our plays and misplays that we are going to obviously not have today, but I think we have Susan Delacourt, Toronto Star columnist, who has been writing about this quite a bit as we all have been covering. Susan, are you surprised at the announcement today?

SUSAN DELACOURT (Toronto Star): Yes, I am, although I can see how it got to this. And actually I was in the middle of talking about this half an hour ago when we were sort of trying to game out how this ended, and this is how it ended. As soon as, I think it was during Jagmeet Singh's questioning at committee last week that I realized this is not going to work. It was, we just realized that what Mr. Johnson had done so far was incomplete, the way forward was too sketchy, and then we have all this distraction of the various communication firms and reputation management advice he was seeking. So the combination of all those three just made me think this is not going to last. I'm still surprised. It's Friday, 5:30.

NAPIER: Quickly, so what could happen next? I mean it's sort of like we all thought that he should, that he had become too much of a distraction. Now he has done it, Susan, what next?

DELACOURT: I think there's got to be a public inquiry. I think, you know, parliament has spoken on this. And I think we talked about this last week on the show, I think that was another misstep. Whether the Liberals like it or not, and whether it's all the opposition parties or not, parliament has spoken on this, and I think that, I think it's back to the drawing board and a public inquiry, and let's start talking about foreign interference.

NAPIER: Interesting, because in his letter of resignation to the prime minister, he writes, I encourage you, to the prime minister, this is David Johnston saying I encourage you to appoint a respected person with national security experience to complete the work that I recommended in my first report. Ideally you would consult with opposition parties to identify suitable candidates to lead this effort. Would that be something, I think we have a few minutes left, so I want to hear from you, Anne, is that the way to go? The parties get together and they find one person they all agree on, or is this the prerogative of the government?

MCGRATH: Well I suspect there will be no way to get all parties to agree on anything.

NAPIER: No? You don't think that could happen?

MCGRATH: I don't think so. Maybe I'm too cynical, but there's not going to be agreement on everything, but they should be consulted for sure. I think all the opposition parties should be consulted. But it is a decision, in my view anyway, of the government. There are ways of moving past the kind of need to have everybody, like you could have someone appointed from each party, and they could meet and make a decision, so there are ways to deal with it for sure.

NAPIER: So, you know, will the leader of the Conservative party, as he has refused to see all the documents and all the evidence in this case, will he refuse to participate in consultations to find somebody?

DELOREY: Good question. Mr. Poilievre has said that he wants to have a say. That's not the same as being consulted. It's more of he wants a more determinant outcome of it where he has to sign off, which I think will be problematic. I don't see why any government would do that, so I don't see how that's going to work.

MACEACHERN: I don't share Anne's entire cynicism, but it's going to be tough. I mean the day that Johnston was announced, I watched two senior members of the press gallery agree that he was a good appointment, and then suddenly after the Conservatives criticized, they changed their tune. That was remarkable. It speaks to how over, the temperature in Ottawa is very, very high. I think he has to consult. It's a minority government, this is a very serious situation, and he has to consult the opposition leaders.

NAPIER: That's quite extraordinary. We thought it was going to be a quiet Friday. What happened to our quiet Friday? I think that is all the time we have. Greg, Anne, Fred, Susan, thank you for stepping up, and for, you know, helping us, you know, unpack this latest news. To those who are just joining us, this is, David Johnston, the special rapporteur, the former governor general has resigned, wrote a letter to the prime minister this afternoon telling him that he will no longer, he no longer can continue in that role. So thank you very much for being there. And that's your Power Play week in politics. Thank you for joining us. The Debate with Mike Le Couteur is coming up next right after today's top headlines. Have a lovely weekend.

urn:contentItem:689X-YKT1-JDV5-F3TT-00000-00UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program2023-05-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1UPDATED MAP: Mississauga's photo radar speed camera locations and what to know about the growing program


Mississauga's photo radar cameras were activated in summer 2021 and the city's program is expanding. Here are a few things to know about Mississauga's speed cameras, including their locations.

Timeline

Mississauga council approved the city's automated speed enforcement (ASE) program as part of the 2020 budget, with the original launch date planned for September of that year.



City staff said delays related to the COVID-19 pandemic slowed down the roll-out of the program.

In May, now former Ward 9 Coun. Pat Saito successfully moved a motion to accelerate plans for more speed cameras in the city, boosting the program from two cameras to 22 by the end of 2021.

The City of Mississauga's first two photo radar cameras became active July 5 in 2021 with units in Malton and Erin Mills neighbourhoods.

City officials said they planned to activate the remaining 20 speed cameras by the end of 2021. According to a report from the city, all 22 were operational by April 2022.

As of Thursday, May 25, 18 speed cameras were active, according to the city.

Tickets

City staff estimated in 2020 that 22 photo radar units would generate 160,000 charges annually.

According to a Mississauga press release, 495 speeding tickets came from the first two speed camera locations, Morning Star Drive and Sawmill Valley Drive, which were in place from July 5 to the first week of August 2021.

In an emailed statement, the city's road safety supervisor Colin Patterson wrote that Mississauga's photo-radar cameras issued another 4,827 speeding tickets between August and December of 2021.

As of June 3, the city reported that 8,258 tickets have been issued in total for the program but only around 25 per cent of the associated fines had been paid.

During that time approximately 1,600 additional vehicles were caught speeding by the city's photo-radar units but were not ticketed due in part to a provincial requirement to issue fines within 30 days of the offence.

At least 23,000 tickets were issued through the photo-radar program in 2022.

urn:contentItem:6362-DX51-JD2C-J3JM-00000-00B.C. should declare state of emergency on forest fires, MLA Clovechok says2021-07-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisNEWSB.C. should declare state of emergency on forest fires, MLA Clovechok says

Columbia River Revelstoke MLA Doug Clovechok is concerned that Premier Horgan has yet to declare a state of emergency given the forest fire situation. He says it would raise awareness with the rest of the country on how severe the situation in British Columbia is, and perhaps make even more resources available. A petition has been launched at change.org requesting a state of emergency and has amassed almost 15,000 signatures.

Horgan said last week that a move to a state of emergency was not necessary yet, saying that he would call it when it was required by fire fighting professionals, and that they hadn't asked for it yet.

With a weather forecast of continued hot, dry days and a fire situation rapidly worsening, the question of whether the backcountry should be closed to at least recreational use has also been raised.

Clovechok was one of the first to call for a backcountry closure in 2018, the last very severe fire year.

He says he did have a conversation with the Minister last week and asked that very question.

"They haven't made a decision on that yet," Clovechok said. "I think it's prudent to consider it, but you have to follow the advise of the experts."

There are many things to consider about backcountry closure, he said, including the fact that having people in the backcountry can be a good thing as they can report smoke or fires that haven't yet been spotted.

In the meantime, given how early in the fire season it still is, Clovechok is imploring anyone who heads into the backcountry to be extremely careful.

"This is dire," he said. "It's mid-July. It's not even fire season yet. I implore everyone to be careful."

urn:contentItem:635V-FSC1-F0HF-81BN-00000-00Wildfire: 13 properties evacuated near Westwold2021-07-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:40:32ZLexisNexisNEWSWildfire: 13 properties evacuated near Westwold

The White Rock Lake wildfire burning southwest of Westwold is now estimated at around 3,000 hectares in size and some nearby residents have been evacuated.

Discovered Tuesday, July 13, the out-of-control blaze has 213 properties in the Thompson-Nicola Regional District on evacuation alert in Electoral Areas L and M, including Westwold.

An evacuation order was called Sunday, July 18, for 13 properties along Douglas Lake Road between 7820 and 8640.

Evacuees can register at the McArthur Island Sports Centre in Kamloops or self-register using the Evacuee Registration and Assistance Tool.

Those who can't stay with family or friends can report to the Salvation Army building on Sutherland Avenue in Kelowna for group lodging.

BC Wildfire Service said fire behaviour continues to be driven by winds.

The fire is being actioned by 12 firefighters, three helicopters, nine pieces of heavy equipment and one structural protection unit.

Wildfire personnel and aerial resources continue efforts with industry partners on site.

The provincial agency reports the fire of note impacted hydro lines in the area, with multiple outages linked to smoke yesterday (Sunday, July 18).

Neighbours in Falkland are reminding others to keep hearts and homes open to those affected.

Area resident Dean Trumbley shared some footage of the smoke-covered community on the Falkland BC Facebook page.

"Welcome to British Columbia during forest fire season," Trumbley wrote. "We have a fire that is just outside our neighbouring community of Westwold. Anything we can do to help, we are glad to do it."
